characters: IN ANOTHER PART OF THE CATACOMBS
SEND FOR THE ROYAL DOG CATCHER
AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL
TELL ME WHAT YOU KNOW ABOUT JULIET
JUST DOWN THE TUNNEL A LITTLE LATER
WANT TO FIND THE MONGRELS IN THE PIAZZA, JUST LISTEN FOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two large wooden doors open into a BEAUTIFUL LIBRARY. Bou leather books sit in mahogany bookshelves. Vaulted ceilin and ornate furniture suggest this place was made very lon ago. The CAMERA slowly approaches a table where a FINELY CRAFT BOOK lies open. The page reads “Chapter One,” and a color illustration shows an Italian town in the hills. Suddenly we HEAR a little voice call us ...

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Psst! Up here! We look up and see an adorable little bat, hanging upside down in the corner of the library. This is FLYER.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: It’s me, Flyer. Unable to contain his excitement, Flyer swoops down and l beside the book. He gestures toward the open page. FLYER (cont'd) Here to read the most romantic love story the world has ever known? (Hopefully) Mind if I read with you? I love a love story. The CAMERA moves in closer to the page’s illustration. In second or two we are INSIDE THE PICTURE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We approach A DELIGHTFUL LITTLE TOWN tucked into a small valley between picturesque mountains. A full moon hangs i the cloudless sky.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Besides ... this story took place in my hometown. Verona. As we swoop down closer, the town’s towers and spires ris meet us. We circle around THE CATHEDRAL and come in for a closer look. The bell in the tower is ringing. Hanging upside down in the window of the BELFRY is a younger vers of Flyer. FLYER (V.O) (cont'd) I used to hang out in the Belfry. He drops out of the window and flies with us down a COBBLESTONE LANE lined with homes as pretty as gingerbrea houses. Lights flicker in nearly every window.  FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) I was just a young whipper-snapper at the time ... As we approach THE PIAZZA where townsfolk happily call ou farewells to one another, Flyer bumps into a sign hanging front of The Butcher’s Store and knocks himself silly. FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) +-. working out the kinks in my radar ... A moment later Flyer has gotten himself going again and approaches A BEAUTIFUL VILLA. A GROUP OF BIRDS are sitting on the banister of the balco watching something below. Flyer lands between a couple of PRETTY WHITE DOVES and tries to put his wings around them FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) «+. this was back in my unpopular days The Doves look at one another clearly frightened of Flyer FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) .--- back when everyone thought we bats were scary! IN A FLASH the Doves dart to the other side of the balcon where they clearly feel a lot more comfortable. All the other birds turn their backs on Flyer and look down into street. Flyer has to flap up onto the roof of the balcony get a view of ... A young man looking up to the balcony longingly, where a young woman looks sadly toward the moon. These young love are of course ROMEO and JULIET.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: But soft! What light through yonder window breaks? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun!

dialogues.speaker: FLYER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Wait a second ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey! "(Whistling loudly) Wait a second, I said! A GIGANTIC IMAGE OF THE OLDER FLYER steps into our view o the lovers and blocks it almost completely. FLYER (cont'd) Wrong-o! Cease it! Cut! The CAMERA moves back to reveal FLYER standing in front the open book in the library. The picture on the page is of Romeo and Juliet. Flyer takes a step or two away from the book much like a trial lawyer about to spring a surprise on a witness. Suddenly he turns back to the page and points to the pict accusingly ... FLYER (cont'd) That is not the most romantic love story the world’s ever known! (Mockingly) Oh no no no no no. Far from it! The picture on the page of the book becomes animated agai Flyer looks at the young lovers almost disdainfully. FLYER (cont'd) I mean, yes, if you’re going to be technical about it. The story you’re talking about is nice. It has its moments ... On the balcony Juliet looks deeply into Romeo’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What’s in a name! That which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: ‘Course, some of the dialogue’s a little much, if you ask me. Now, if you want to see the most romantic story ... you got to look ... (Pointing to the corner of the picture) -.. down here ... The CAMERA now begins to RE-ENTER the illustration where Flyer has gestured to. FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) .+. where only I could see it, sitting up there on the roof. The CAMERA moves slowly down off the balcony, down the si of the building, past the swooning Romeo, across the stre and down an embankment. FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) This story comes from an entirely different part of Verona ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our view continues moving down to beside the river, where handsome golden retriever puppy watches Romeo’s every ges with admiration. This is ROVER.  FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) And involves different characters altogether. Two other puppies hang out nearby. BENNY, a goofy looking basset hound, chases his tail in circles, kicking up mud everywhere. MERCURY, a brown and black bulldog, exercises rigorously, further sculpting his already fine-tuned four legged physique. FLYER (V.O) (cont'd) Though these characters from time to time may seem a little familiar ... Rover sighs loudly, completely oblivious to his friends’ canine concerns.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Oh, I wish I was in love. Benny momentarily stops his twirling and looks at Rover.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Love? What do you want to be in love for, Rover? All that sniffing each other and stuff. Yeech!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: But Benny, then you have somebody, and they have you.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: You have more than that.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Rover, just think about it, would you? Oh sure, it’s all fun in the beginning. Candlelight dinners at the cozy trash can behind the butchers’. Making puppy-dog eyes at one another. But then things change. One thing leads to another. Pretty soon you got a litter full of problems to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I suppose ... but still, I want to be in love ... Benny has resumed his tail-chasing routine. Mercury turns him clearly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Benny, dog gone it! Don’t you know you’re never gonna catch your tail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Continuing to chase his tail) Yes, I am! Yes I am! I almost ... got it ... And he promptly chases his tail ... right into the river! second later he comes up for air, panicking ... BENNY (cont'd) I can’t swim! I can’t swim! Mercury, help me!

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Just don’t panic!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Paddle!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Dog paddle. Benny seems to get the hang of it. MERCURY (cont'd) That's it. A moment later Benny pulls himself ashore, completely drenched. MERCURY (cont'd) What did I tell you? But would you listen? No!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: But I almost had it that time, I swear. Just as Benny shakes himself off we hear a DEEP AUTHORITA VOICE ...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: And just what are you pups up to? The three young dogs turn and discover a pack of street-w dogs who peer down at them sternly. One of the older dogs clearly the leader. This is Rover's father, BIG DADDY MONGREL. Big Daddy is dripping wet and clearly unamused. The young dogs leap to attention guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stammering) N - nothing, Big Daddy. W - we’re j - just -

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: Doggin’ it! You boys are supposed to be off collecting scraps.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: I tried to tell them, sir, but they wouldn't listen. Big Daddy Mongrel gives Rover a disapproving look. Rover lowers his eyes ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: Come here, son. Big Daddy Mongrel puts a paw on Rover’s shoulder and look into his eyes. BIG DADDY MONGREL (cont’d) You’re almost a year old now. Don’t you think it’s about time you start acting like it?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I know, I know ...

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: Your mother and I got hopes for you. You think I got to be the top dog rolling around in the daisies? No. You got to work for it.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: He says he wants to be in love, Big Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: What? Is that true, Rover?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Well ... yes.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: You spend too much time playing fetch with Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with Romeo. He’s nice to me. He brings me biscuits and scratches behind my ears -

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: Well! If Romeo is so nice ... Big Daddy Mongrel stares at his son truly angry now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ++. Can you tell me why he’s falling in love ... Big Daddy Mongrel points dramatically up to Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: +.. with a CAT OWNER! !

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Juliet owns cats?

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: Where do you think the Cat-Pulet’s live, boy? Big Daddy Mongrel looks at Romeo disdainfully. BIG DADDY MONGREL (cont’d) That boy’s probably got cat hair all over him by now.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: (Disillusioned) No!

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY MONGREL
dialogues.text: So let me hear no more of Romeo or love. They are dangerous influences. Rover nods sadly. It is like he has lost a hero. BIG DADDY MONGREL (cont’d) Now get out there and get us some scraps!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Yes, Father. The three young dogs leave their elders with their tails between their legs. After a moment, Rover takes a last lo up to the balcony. ROVER (cont'd) I didn’t know Juliet owns cats. Our view now begins to focus on Juliet’s window.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? She’s got more cats than I got fleas.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Can you believe that? Actually liking cats?  INT. JULIET’S BEDROOM Inside Juliet’s window we see that the young lover sits o chair crying for Romeo. In her sadness, she reaches for a black and white, nearly full-grown kitten.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They say she even pets them... Juliet puts the kitten on her lap. MERCURY (0.S.) (cont’d) Sometimes they even sit on her lap!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's so ... so... tragic. Juliet looks in the kitten’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh Juliet, true friend Juliet, what dost thou think I should do? LADY AND LORD CAT-PULET, two immaculately groomed long-ha cats, sit on Juliet’s vanity table. They are the kitten’s parents. When Lady Cat-Pulet hears the girl call the kitt “Juliet,” she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: I still can’t believe that girl named her pet after herself!

dialogues.speaker: LORD CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: You have to remember, the child’s only fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: I’m fourteen, too! You see me doing anything so foolish?

dialogues.speaker: LORD CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: No dear ... The human Juliet (hereafter referred to as “Juliet the Gi sets the kitten Juliet (hereafter referred to as “Juliet” her lap. Then she takes a tissue and looks longingly out window.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET THE GIRL
dialogues.text: (Sniffling) Dost thou think Romeo will be true? Below Juliet the Girl’s chair sits DOC, a persian cat wit furtive eyes and a manner of speaking very akin to Mae We When she and the other cats talk near people, they do so under their breaths, and it is very clear that humans are aware that the animals are talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please ... Juliet the Girl lets her tissue drop to the ground. Doc picks it up and hands it to Lady and Lord Cat-Pulet on th vanity table. Lord Cat-Pulet is taking the tissues from D and writing on them with an eye-liner. Lady Cat-Pulet put paw-prints on them using ruby-red lipstick. DOC (cont'd) --- doesn’t she know men are dogs? TYGER, a ferocious striped cat with a menacing smile, sit Juliet the Girl’s bed. He practices hurling his claws int picture of a dog like humans throw darts at a dart board.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: You give men a bad name, Doc. Only dogs are dogs.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Maybe baby, but every male of every species has a bit of canine in him. Even you, Tyger. Tyger swats a ball of yarn at Doc, but she dodges it easi

dialogues.speaker: LADY CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: Stop it you two. We have work to do. LADY CAT-PULET (cont'd) Juliet, come on. These invitations for the animal ball have to go out tomorrow. Juliet whispers discreetly as Juliet the Girl continues t cry.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Mother, what am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: LADY CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: Act prissy. It’s every cat’s prerogative.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I can’t do that. Juliet needs me.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (Mocking) Needs you! Until she’s got a date.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: That's not true! Juliet’s different ... Meanwhile, TYBALT, a dashing young human in his late teen has come into Juliet the Girl’s room. He picks Tyger up o the bed and throws him into the air! As Tyger screeches horribly and struggles to land on his feet, Tybalt laughs delightedly.  10.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET THE GIRL
dialogues.text: Tybalt!

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Oh come now dearest cousin, they’re only cats. Juliet the Girl sets Juliet down and crosses to Tyger.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET THE GIRL
dialogues.text: They’re more than that. They’re my friends. She pats Tyger on the head. JULIET THE GIRL (cont’d) You all right, little one? Tyger purrs happily. Juliet turns proudly back to Doc, gesturing to Juliet the Girl.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: You see how Juliet is different?

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Well, thoust will never guess what I did find downstairs after the ball.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET THE GIRL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Evidence that Montagues were there.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET THE GIRL
dialogues.text: Montagues!

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Yes, come this way and I will show you. Tybalt and Juliet the Girl leave. Tyger heads over to the ball of yarn.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Come on, help me roll this up.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I can’t stand yarn.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: How can you be a cat and not like a ball of yarn?  11.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She leaps to the window sill and looks outside longingly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I like the ball in the sky. What do you call that?

dialogues.speaker: LADY CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: It’s the moon.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: The moon. Oh I think it is so beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Beautiful? What’s so beautiful about the moon. Next you’ll be howling like a dog at it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But I think it’s beautiful. I do. She looks at the globed lamp posts.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: And the balls of light outside. And the balls that people throw to one another in the park. Sometimes I see balls bouncing down the street so fast. Not like balls of yarn that roll a couple feet and stop. But balls that go faster and faster. Sometimes I want to chase those balls. Right outside, into the big wide world. Lady and Lord Cat-Pulet look at one another concerned. Lo Cat-Pulet clears his throat and gives Doc a look that mea something like, “will you talk some sense into the girl?” Doc sets down her work and goes up to Juliet on the windo sill.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Juliet, you’re not feeling ... curious are you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How many times do I have to tell you that curiosity kills -

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But I don’t see why it has to. Don’t you ever wonder, Doc, what it must be like to live outside? MEANWHILE OUTSIDE ...  12. Rover, Benny and Mercury are looking for scraps. Mercury scans the contents of some trash cans they’ve just dumped over much as a construction foreman oversees a project.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Nothin’ here, come on. He immediately heads off toward the next alley. As soon a he’s out of sight, Benny jumps on top of one of the trash cans like a western log-roller. Rover takes one whiff of garbage and grimaces. A second later he glances up to a window. It is not Juliet’s window.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Benny?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (Trying to balance himself) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Have you ever wondered what it must be like to live ... inside? The sound of the word “inside” literally sends Benny hurl He falls face first into a barrel. A moment later he reappears covered in goop.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Inside?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You think you’re some kind of poodle, or something?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: No, no, I just wonder. Don’t you ever wonder? INSIDE ... Juliet looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I imagine flowers and sunshine and leaping in the trees. There’d be wide open spaces and rivers and lakes and you could go swimming! Doc gives Juliet a look like she has gone completely off rocker. OUTSIDE ... Rover continues to peer into windows longingly.  13.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I imagine a fireplace and music and chewing a shoe. There’d be food served in bowls and I'd wear bells ... anda ribbon in my hair. Benny puts a paw on Rover’s forehead to make sure he does have a fever. INSIDE ... Juliet leads Doc into the kitchen, where we see pet dishe the floor. Tyger tails along behind, looking on suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Don’t you ever get tired of warm milk and cold tuna and wearing these tight collars?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: But they’re diamond studded. You know how I love studs.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Call me crazy, but in my dreams I see myself standing on a tall bridge, taking off this horrid collar and throwing it into the river! OUTSIDE ... Rover turns a corner and directs Benny’s attention to a g of sad and lonely dogs struggling to survive in the stree Mercury looks at his two friends with concern.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Don’t you ever get tired of dog catchers and cold nights and digging in the trash?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I love trash!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Call me crazy, but in my dreams I see myself settling down to sleep on a satin pillow beside my master’s bed. INSIDE ... Juliet leaps to the kitchen window and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: That's what the outside would be, a place where I could be me, a place where I could be ...

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: What?  14.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Free. OUTSIDE ... Rover jumps a short hedge and peers in the front window o charming little home. Benny is right behind.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: That's the kind of place that I crave, a place where you don’t even have to be brave, a place where for once I would be

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dreamy smile spreads across Benny’s face as he gets cau up in Rover's fantasy. INSIDE ... Doc has nearly the exact same look on her face, but Tyger SCREECHES and brings an end to that.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: It’s not all fun and games out there, you know?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: It isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: There’s lots of stuff you have to do that isn’t fun.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Well ... like scratching yourself for instance.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Scratching myself? But whatever for?

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Because you’1ll have fleas!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Fleas! My goodness!

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: And what’s more ... Tyger whispers something in Juliet’s ear that surprises h  15.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Really!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But I don’t even know what a fire hydrant is! OUTSIDE ... Mercury SNARLS at Rover as well.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Don’t kid yourself, home sweet home ain’t all it’s cracked up to be.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: It isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Well, because you have to keep yourself clean.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Clean? What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: It means you have to lick yourself all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: And you even have to ... Mercury whispers in Rover’s ear. Rover turns to him startled.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: In a box?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: In_a_box! INSIDE ... Tyger and Doc lead Juliet back into the bedroom.  16.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: So don’t get yourself all excited. It’s a jungle out there, kiddo. OUTSIDE ... Mercury and Benny lead Rover back to the trash cans.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: So don’t go getting a bunch of ideas. It can be war in there, buster. INSIDE ... As Doc and Tyger go back to work on the invitations, Juli looks out the window again.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Still, sometimes I can’t help wonder ... OUTSIDE ... Rover looks up to a window again as Mercury and Benny go to scrounging.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Still, sometimes I can’t help wonder ...

dialogues.speaker: SPLIT SCREEN
dialogues.text: Both Rover and Juliet look forlornly toward the different worlds they seek.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What it would be like ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: What it would be like ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: +.. to live outside.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: +.. to live inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colorful town square is teeming with SHOPPERS. Italia VENDORS peddle everything from fresh produce to fine clothing. The camera pans down through the crowd until we are almost ground-level in front of a WATCHMAKER’S KIOSK. Passing by are the legs and feet of busy shoppers. SUDDENLY, Rover’s head pops out from under the red curtai that encircles the kiosk. He anxiously looks around, maki sure not to be seen.  17.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: (From behind the curtain) How’s it look, Rover? Rover looks directly across from the watchmaker’s kiosk a THE MEAT STAND. A FAT BUTCHER is in the process of cutting steaks and cho for his customers. Rover licks his lips ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Like dinner! And then some! With that, a GIANT PAW pulls Rover behind the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiding behind the curtain are Benny and Mercury. Big Dadd Mongrel holds Rover by a tuft of hair.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: This is a delicate operation, boys. One wrong move could land you in the pound.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: (Cocky) Not to worry, Pops ... Big Daddy looks at him sternly.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: (Gulping) --. I mean, Big Daddy. Big Daddy finally puts a relieved Rover down.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: Benny, I need you to cause a distraction. Something wild.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (Still trying to catch his own tail) How do I do that, Big Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: Trust me. Just be yourself. Mercury, you back up Rover while he’s nabbing the goods.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: You can count on me, Big Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: Good luck, boys. Make this old Mongrel proud. The three dogs head out. Big Daddy is clearly worried abo  18. his pups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Mercury make their way towards the meat stand. Benny lags behind.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Something wild ... something wild ... Benny notices a JUGGLER performing for a group of childre The juggler has several red balls in the air. Behind him a vegetable stand. Benny spots a_pile of ripe tomatoes and suddenly has an i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While The Butcher is busy helping his customers, Rover an Mercury sneak up from behind. Benny positions himself in crowd. Rover waits, then gives Benny the signal. With that, Benn begins to BARK as loud as he can. The crowd of people tur to look. Amazingly, Benny climbs up on his hind legs and JUGGLES T TOMATOES WITH HIS FRONT PAWS. People ooh and aah. Even The Butcher watches in amazement. Meanwhile, Rover jumps onto the meat counter and begins pushing steaks and chops down to Mercury. Benny continues to juggle for the adoring crowd. In no ti at all he is up to twelve tomatoes! But when Benny goes f number thirteen, they all come tumbling down on his head. Benny is left covered in tomato juice. The crowd sighs and returns to shopping. It is then that Butcher finally notices what Rover is doing.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Hey, you stinky mongrel! Those are my steaks! The Butcher picks up his MEAT CLEVER, but just before he slice Rover in two ... BUTCHER (cont'd) Aaaaaaah!!!! Mercury BITES him on the leg, giving Rover the chance to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover runs through the crowd. When he turns for a split second to see if he’s being chased, the terrified pup ...  19. SLAMS RIGHT INTO A PAIR OF LEGS. A bit dazed, Rover looks and finds ... .-. ROMEO staring right down at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Alas, ‘tis my favorite stray. Romeo scoops up Rover, who still has a steak hanging in h mouth. ROMEO (cont'd) Thou art a criminal in need of a place to hide. Come. We shall find you a fine wine to go with your meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercury and Benny, still covered in tomatoes, make their home.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: You had to be a hot shot, didn’t you. Like a dog juggling twelve tomatoes wasn’t enough of a distraction. You just had to go for thirteen!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I like to challenge myself.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Believe me, Big Daddy is going to do more than that when he finds out we blew the caper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, still holding Rover, looks through the many wines.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Wine seller, bring me your most prized vintage. Tonight is a special occasion. The Wine Seller bows and goes in back. Romeo leans down a whispers to Rover, unaware that the dog can understand ev word he says. ROMEO (cont'd) Can you keep a secret, my friend? I, a Montague, am to marry Juliet, a Capulet, in secret tonight at the old church. As if on cue, AN EXPENSIVE HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE appears i the piazza. Lord and Lady Capulet step out, followed by their evil nephew, Tybalt. Tybalt spots Romeo and throws him a nasty look.  20. ROMEO (cont'd) Perhaps our marriage can finally bring this feud between our families to an end. EXT. CAPULET’S CARRIAGE When The Capulets are well out of sight, the carriage’s b compartment pops open and out jumps Tyger. He makes sure that the coast is clear, then calls for his henchcats.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Shake! Speare! SHAKE and SPEARE, two Siamese cats who bear an amazing resemblance to The Bard, slowly climb out of the carriage

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: To be ...

dialogues.speaker: SPEARE
dialogues.text: Or not to be ...

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Where are the party invitations? Shake and Speare look at one another and shrug.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Now that is the question. Frustrated, Tyger WHOOPS them both on the head. He then jumps back into the carriage, locates the invitations and throws them down.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Make sure every animal gets one. The henchcats scoop up the invitations and head off into piazza.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Friends...!

dialogues.speaker: SPEARE
dialogues.text: Romans...!

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Country mice...!

dialogues.speaker: SPEARE
dialogues.text: Lend me your ears! Tyger shakes his head in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: I gotta get me some new henchcats ... Just then, Tyger spots Rover in Romeo’s arms. The two mak eye contact. Tyger hisses and throws the nervous puppy a  21. look as nasty as Tybalt’s. He comes after Rover, ready to attack. EXT. WINE SELLER’S KIOSK As Tyger approaches, Rover jumps out of Romeo’s arms and makes a run for it.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Hey! Where’s thou going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover runs through the piazza and winds up in a dark and scary alley. He comes to a dead end, and when he tries to turn around, Tyger suddenly JUMPS down right in front of

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Don’t you know stray dogs aren’t allowed in the piazza?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Well, um...

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: All I'd have to do is get the dog catcher’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: (Trying to be brave) Why don’t you leave me alone. I wasn’t bothering you.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: You're a dog. Your mere existence bothers me. Tyger moves closer, menacingly. TYGER (cont'd) It's been a long time since I clawed anyone. Almost a week. Tyger raises his razor sharp claws above Rover's head.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you pick on somebody your own size. Tyger turns to find Mercury and Benny.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Two against one. Not what you’d call a fair fight. Mercury pushes Benny to the side with Rover.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: How’s that?  22.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: That’s not fair either. For you, that is ... Tyger LUNGES at Mercury. The two animals literally fight like cats and dogs, rolling all the way back into the pia People run and scream to get out of the way. EXT. THE PRINCE’S ROYAL BOX From his seat high above the piazza, THE PRINCE notices t commotion. He signals for his PAGE.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRINCE
dialogues.text: What’s going on down there?

dialogues.speaker: PAGE
dialogues.text: It looks like a cat and dog fighting, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRINCE
dialogues.text: Just what I need. More fighting! Noticing that The Prince is agitated, a SERVANT races to side and begins massaging his temples. THE PRINCE (cont’d) As if The Capulets and The Montagues weren’t enough of a headache. Send for my royal dog catcher to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: PAGE
dialogues.text: Yes, my liege. (Shouting)

dialogues.speaker: SEND FOR THE ROYAL DOG CATCHER
dialogues.text: The command is heard repeated by a series of pages until reaches ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cages are teeming with strays. THE ROYAL DOG CATCHER, tall and sinister-looking fellow dressed entirely in blac polishes his silver dog catcher’s net.

dialogues.speaker: DOG CATCHER
dialogues.text: (Smiling) Party time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercury and Tyger are still going at it, knocking over everything in their path. With all of his strength, Mercu pushes Tyger to the ground and raises his paw in the air.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Say nighty-night, Kitty.  23. A GALLOPING SOUND is suddenly heard. Rover turns and find the Dog Catcher racing toward him on his black horse.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Merc’, it’s the fuzz! Mercury looks up and sees the dog catcher’s net about to swoop down on Rover! He jumps off of Tyger and pushes his friend out of the way just in the nick of time. The three dogs make a run for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The puppies race to get out of the piazza. But The Dog Catcher is right on their tails, whipping his horse to ru faster.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: He’s almost got us!

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: This way! Mercury leads the dogs through a narrow passage between t kiosks. But as Rover tries to escape, THE DOG CATCHER GRA

dialogues.speaker: DOG CATCHER
dialogues.text: (ala The Wicked Witch) I’ve got you my pretty...! But The Dog Catcher’s wrong. Mercury and Benny, pulling Rover from the other side, save their friend. Rover’s tai slips right through The Dog Catcher’s hands. DOG CATCHER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: NOLLIL
dialogues.text: He watches as the three dogs vanish into the streets. DOG CATCHER (cont’d) Next time your tail is mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs stop to catch their breath.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: That was too close for comfort.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: You’re telling me! Thanks for saving my tail, guys.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Anytime. In the gutter, TWO RATS hold one of the Cat-Pulets’ party invitations.  24.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RAT
dialogues.text: What are you going as?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND RAT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I always wanted to be a hamster.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RAT
dialogues.text: A hamster? That’s so obvious.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: What are you rats talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RAT
dialogues.text: We just got invited to the social event of the season. Any animal who’s anyone will be there.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Hey, we’re animals. (Thinking) Aren’t we?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Lemme see that ... Mercury grabs the invitation. It reads, ‘LORD AND LADY CAT-PULET CORDIALLY INVITE YOU TO THEIR COSTUME BALL. PLEASE RSVP. P.S. NO DOGS ALLOWED!’ MERCURY (cont'd) Well if that don’t beat all. The furballs are having a ball. And we ain’t invited.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: No big surprise, seeing how much they hate us.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Maybe so. But if this shindig is good enough for a bunch of rats ...

dialogues.speaker: RATS
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: --. well then it’s good enough for a bunch of dogs. And I think I know just how to get even with Tyger in the process. You boys game?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Absolutely!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Just as long as I don’t have to juggle.  25. THE NIGHT OF THE CAT-PULET’S PARTY - MONTAGE Animals throughout Verona don various costumes. EXT. VERONA’S ZOO - MONTAGE The monkeys swipe the sleeping zookeeper’s keys and let t other exotic animals out of their cages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A virtual menagerie makes its way through the city toward Cat-Pulet’s villa. Some of the animals are easy to recogn under their costumes (the elephant dressed as a kangaroo, example), while others are completely disguised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord and Lady Cat-Pulet greet their guests as they arrive the front gates. When the elephant shows up, they have hi go around back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oriental-looking building. A statue of a red dragon ha over its entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed as three skunks, Rover, Mercury, and Benny roll fireworks out of their boxes and into a brown sack. But when Benny goes to scratch himself, one of the unlit fireworks flies into the air. Fortunately, Rover catches just in time.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Careful, Benny!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Sorry. But this costume itches. (Sniffing himself) And it smells bad too.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: You're supposed to smell bad. You’re a

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: (Holding up one of the bottle rockets) Mercury, are you sure this plan is going to work?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Trust me. By the time we’re through, those cats won’t know what hit ‘em.  26. INT. JULIET’S BEDROOM Doc, dressed as a sexy cheetah, and Juliet, dressed as a polar bear cub, put some last minute touches on their costumes.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Terrific. You’re going to knock ‘em dead tonight, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, the cheetah is the fastest cat on earth ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Zip me up. Doc helps Juliet into her costume. It is now impossible t tell that she is a cat. EXT. THE CAT-PULETS’ VILLA The dogs, hidden entirely under their skunk costumes, fol Mercury across the street to the party. The Cat-Pulets, unaware of who they are, greet them at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: My, what clever costumes.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I’m smelly and I’m darn proud of it! Mercury suddenly notices that Benny’s tail is beginning t stick out. He rushes to get Benny passed The Cat-Pulets.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Come on, big mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire place is wall to wall with animals. An orchest made up of penguins plays classical music. Flyer, dressed a peacock, dances in mid-air with an eagle. When the dogs enter, they make a bee-line for the buffet.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Get a load of this spread!

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Eat up, boys. In a few minutes, this party’s going to be history.  27. MEANWHILE ... Doc is surrounded by various animals who want to dance wi her.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Please don’t fight. I’m only one kitty! Juliet smiles at her friend’s good fortune. But her smile suddenly turns into a frown when she sees her parents and VIENNA, a snobby Viennese bachelor cat, approaching.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: Juliet, you remember Vienna, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (Grimacing) Of course. Vienna, dressed as a unicorn, smiles lasciviously.

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA
dialogues.text: Juliet, how purr-fect you look tonight! Vienna bends down to kiss Juliet’s paw but pokes her with horn. Juliet screams.

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA
dialogues.text: I’m soooo sorry! I’m not used to being mythological. Vienna laughs at his own lame joke. Juliet’s had just abo enough of this drip.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me? I think I see a monkey I know by the buffet.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: The orchestra finishes its song. The animals applaud.

dialogues.speaker: PENGUIN ORCHESTRA LEADER
dialogues.text: The boys and I are going to take five for a couple of ice cubes. Flyer’s dance partner smiles and gives him a peck on the cheek as she flies off. He sighs and looks at his peacock feathers.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: This is the one night each year when nobody's afraid of me. (Looking over at his dance partner) I sure wouldn’t mind another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs are seriously digging in. But as Rover reaches across the table, his black, skunk paw accidentally bumps into a white, furry one. He looks up and finds none other than Juliet herself. Their eyes meet and it is LOVE AT FIRST SIGHT!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Wow ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: You have the most amazing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: So do you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: You can tell a lot about someone from their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? What do mine say?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: That you’re honest ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Uh .. well ... usually.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: And that you’re looking for something. Or maybe, someone. Rover and Juliet stare at one another, transfixed. Just then, the orchestra starts up again. JULIET (cont'd) Would you like to dance ...? Rover is tempted, then looks over at Mercury and Benny and remembers why he is here.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Oh I don’t know ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Come on. It’s easy. And besides, when’s the next time you’re going to see a polar bear and a skunk dancing together? Rover smiles, then gets pulled onto the dance floor by Juliet. A formal, Renaissance-like dance begins. Rover looks around awkwardly, uncertain what to do. Trying to mimic what the others are doing, Rover steps right on Juliet’s foot! It’s all Juliet can do to keep from crying out.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry!  29.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: It’s all right ... Don’t worry about the others. She turns his face to hers. JULIET (cont'd) Look at me. Looking into those eyes, a kind of miracle comes over Rov He boldly twirls Juliet with precision. JULIET (cont'd) That’s it! In no time, Rover and Juliet are dazzling everyone at the party with their dancing prowess. The Cat-Pulets dancing nearby can’t even begin to keep up with them. As the song ends, the spectators applaud for Rover and Juliet. Rover leads her off the dance floor away from the other Cat-Pulets. JULIET (cont'd) I'd say you’re a natural.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I'd say you’re a great teacher.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Not that good.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: In your arms, anything seems possible. Rover looks at Juliet strangely.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Or should I say, “in your paws”, or “in your wings”? She looks back at him furtively.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Are you trying to figure out what I am?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Maybe so.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: That's strictly against the rules, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I like breaking rules.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Well, these aren’t wings. I’m no chicken, that’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a lamb?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: A rabbit?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: A goat?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (Coyly) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Oh come on! I just have to know.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Just have to, huh? What do you say ... (An idea comes over her) .-. I show you instead?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Are you just going to take off your mask?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I will if you will. Rover gulps and looks around fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: How about we go to the garden instead? I’m kinda shy.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: All right, then. 1I/’11 meet you there in five minutes. Juliet hurries off. Rover almost swoons.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I’m in love! Mercury appears in a huff.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: What gives, Rover? We’re here to do some damage, not win a dance contest.  31. Rover sees Juliet walk outside.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I know, I know ... but I think the polar bear is on to us. I’m just trying to keep her ... distracted.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Well hurry it up. Benny’s setting up the pyrotechnics even as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the starry night, Juliet awaits her true love. Rove sneaks up from behind and places his paws over her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Guess who?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: The animal of my dreams?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Close enough. Rover walks around in front of Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Ready ... ? Rover looks around one last time to make sure that the co is clear.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: On the count of three. One ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Two ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET/ROVER
dialogues.text: Three! Rover and Juliet lift their masks. Both are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What are you doing at my family’s party? You must know we, I mean they, hate dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don’t hate dogs too?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I can’t hate someone I don’t even know. That would be silly.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I guess you’re right.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: So what are we going to do? I mean it seemed like we were sort of becoming, I don’t know ... friends.
Yeah, it sure seemed that way. But I just don’t think the world’s ready for a cat and a dog being ... friends.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess not. Both are terribly saddened by this realization.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Well, see ya... Rover puts on his mask and starts back inside.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Hey ... I don’t even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: It’s Rover.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I’m Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: (Gesturing to the balcony) You mean like the girl ...?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet. I like that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I like that too.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Though it does sound vaguely familiar .. Juliet smiles, slightly.  33. ROVER (cont'd) Well ... ‘Night, Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Good night, Rover. Rover leaves. A single tear drop falls from Juliet’s eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover meets up with Mercury and Benny.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Where have you been?! The fireworks are just about to begin.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: You know, Merc’, I don’t think this is such a good idea after all. I mean, maybe The Cat-Pulets aren’t so bad ...

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Are you nuts? We’re finally going to give these stuck up house-fluffers what they deserve. Mercury jumps onto a chair. MERCURY (cont'd) Listen up, animals of Verona! It’s time for tonight’s entertainment, courtesy of the three muske-skunks. Hit it, Benny! Benny pushes down on a GIANT BOMB PLUNGER, setting off th fireworks and bottle rockets. It is chaos as the animals panic and try to flee. In the confusion, Rover finds Juli He pulls off his mask.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Juliet, I’m sorry. I tried to stop them. I really did.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I believe you, Rover. But you better leave before my family gets their hands on you. Rover and Juliet desperately want to kiss before parting, can’t. As Rover flees the mayhem, Tyger spots him.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: I knew it! The Mongrels! As Tyger starts to go after Rover, Lord Cat-pulet stops h  34.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CAT-PULET
dialogues.text: Wait. Now’s not the time for revenge. Help calm our guests. You’ll get that little doggie soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flyer, still in his peacock uniform, is struggling to fly home with all his long tail feathers.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Would you look at this? How you supposed to fly with tail feathers like this? When one of his elongated wings hits a tree branch, Flyer plummets to the earth. FLYER (cont'd) And he falls with a tremendous splash in a bird bath. He ends up completely drenched. FLYER (cont'd) It's hard being beautiful. Dragging himself out of the bird bath, Flyer finds he has peacock feathers sticking out in every direction. Starting to pluck them out left and right, he notices Rov moping in the shadows by the cathedral. FLYER (cont'd) Hey there, Rover. What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Oh, Flyer, it’s terrible!

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I’m in love! At least I think I’m in love.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: But Rover that’s wonderful! You've wanted to be in love forever!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I know, I know, but ...

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: -.. it’s with a ... Cat-Pulet!  35.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: You mean Juliet?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: (Confused) And that’s a problem?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Flyer! She’s a cat!

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: And I’m a dog! Flyer gives Rover a perplexed look. ROVER (cont'd) Can’t you see? I don’t think the world is ready for a dog-cat relationship.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: The world? Rover, since when have you ever worried about what the world thinks, huh? Flyer looks at Rover, but the dog lowers his eyes. FLYER (cont'd) This is more about what you think, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I’m just so confused. I don’t know if I should ... I don’t even know if I could -+- Do you know any dog who would ...?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Love a cat?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Rover shakes his head and walks away from Flyer dejected.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Rover ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: What? Flyer finally has his entire costume off and flies over a lands in front Rover.  36.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Rover!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. When you look at me, what do you see?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: What do you mean, what do I see? I see you. Flyer.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: And do you see that I’m a bat?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Of course, I see that you’re a bat.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: So then why aren’t you ... Flyer bares his pathetically short fangs, not looking eve remotely frightening ...

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: -.. afraid of me, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Why would I ever be afraid of you?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Because a lot of creatures think I’m scary.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: They do?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, they don’t even like me being around. Flyer takes a hop toward a couple of squirrels, who immediately scram in opposite directions.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: See what I mean? Without that peacock costume I would never have gotten in to the animal ball tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: But why are they afraid of you?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe ... Flyer flies under a dark awning and hangs upside down.  37.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: ... it’s because we like hanging upside down in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: What’s scary about that?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Beats me. Flyer comes back down to Rover now.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Maybe they think we carry germs or something, or we’re sneaky because we fly so quiet. Did you know that some creatures even think we’re evil?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Evil?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Four hundred years from now they’re going to be making all these movies about bats who turn into vampires and bite people’s necks and say ... Flyer does his best Bela Lugosi. FLYER (cont'd) “I vant to suck your blood.”

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: But that’s ridiculous! You don’t want to suck anybody’s blood. You’re not a vampire! And you don’t carry germs either. You’re the cleanest, most honest creature in Verona. How could anybody think that you are scary?

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: I don’t know, but somehow they do.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s crazy! Flyer touches Rover’s paw with his wing.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Rover, it’s easy for you to see that it’s crazy when it’s between bats and other animals. But can you see that it’s crazy also when its between cats and dogs? Rover looks into the sky as if he’s been struck by lightening.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: My goodness, you're right. It doesn’t matter if we’re different. What matters is ... is...

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: What’s in your hearts. Rover looks back at Flyer.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Well, I know what’s in mine.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: I guess there’s only one thing left to find out then, isn’t there?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Yes, absolutely! Thank you, Flyer! Thank you! Rover sets of down the street at a full sprint. Flyer watches him go happily.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: ‘Atta boy. INT. JULIET’S BEDROOM Doc is helping Juliet slip out of her polar bear costume she begins to notice that Juliet seems very depressed abo something.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Juliet? You haven’t said a word since the party. But it is as if Juliet is in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. What did you say, Rover?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Rover!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, did I say Rover?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Yes, you did. I’ve been called a lot of things in my day, but Rover isn’t one of them. Juliet ... Doc lifts Juliet’s chin.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Have you been rubbing whiskers with with one of the canine persuasion?  39. Juliet hides her eyes from Doc, but she knows there’s no trying to hide the truth from her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Yes, I have. I met him at the party. We talked. We danced. But in the end ... (starting to cry) Oh Rover, Rover, wherefore art thou Rover! Doc takes a tissue from the vanity table and dries Juliet eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh Doc, you won’t tell anyone, will you?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Of course not. We love kittens got to stick together. Just don’t let Tyger find out. At that moment A LONELY HOWL is heard outside the house. Juliet crosses to the window and looks down into the stre

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: It’s Rover!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Rover?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness!

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Hey, he’s kind of cute.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Well, for a dog...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh, Doc, what am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Go out and talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Talk to him? What do I say?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Say, “Hey ya big boy, why don’t you come up and see me some time?”

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I can’t say that!  40.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Then just be yourself. You'll be fine. Juliet opens the window and slips out on the balcony. Rov clears his throat and begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: But soft! What light from over yonder comes and breaks my window.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: That’s not right. I mean what yonder broke my light ... I mean my window ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Rover, what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I’m saying ... He looks up at her suddenly full of confidence.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I’m saying that I love you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I love you, Juliet. And I want to know if you love me too. Because if you do, then all the differences between us will mean nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh Rover, I do love you. Very much. Rover suddenly flies into a series of back flips. Juliet laughs delightedly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Come to me, Rover.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Come to you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Jump up here.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I can’t jump up there.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Why not?  41.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Because I can’t jump that high. I'ma dog, remember?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh. So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: You’re going to have to come down here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Because I’ve never been out of the house before.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: You've never seen Verona? The most beautiful town in the world?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Then come with me Juliet, and I will show it to you, and you will have the most wonderful night of your life. Juliet looks at Doc questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Just don’t do anything I wouldn’t do.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But there isn’t anything you wouldn’t do. Doc smiles mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Exactly. Taking one last look into her bedroom, Juliet turns and dashes off the balcony. She leaps high into the air and lands right beside Rover. After looking dreamily into his eyes, Juliet finally shrugs shyly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Verona, remember?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Oh yes ... Verona. And what would you like to see first?  42.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: All of it. I want to see all of it. And with that the happy couple darts off into the city, p in paw. Flyer, who has been observing the young lovers fr a tree limb, flaps behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment later, Rover and Juliet are SWINGING AROUND LAMP POSTS and DANCING IN THE STREETS. Juliet is, of course, fascinated by everything she sees, but especially by the of light and the oranges and other round fruits she sees through a market's window. Overcome with chivalry, Rover sneaks in the back door of market and returns a minute later with a couple of nectar that he’s pawned.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Where to next?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (Pointing to the fruit) Throw it.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Throw it! Rover FLINGS the nectarine down the street. Juliet points the direction it has gone. JULIET (cont'd) I want to go there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet have caught up with the rolling fruit. Laughing and giggling, they kick it on further ... straig down the sidewalk and into the opera house. Outside the front door, Rover and Juliet dodge the legs o people entering the opera house. Slowly a DEVILISH GRIN spreads across Juliet’s face and she bolts into the opera house after the nectarine. Rover is right behind her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nectarine is being inadvertently kicked around the fr lobby. Before Rover and Juliet can catch up to it though, is kicked down a back hallway toward a dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet tear after the bouncing nectarine only t become accidentally entangled in TWO ELABORATE COSTUMES.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nectarine continues to roll just out of reach of Rove and Juliet who have now come to be wearing the elaborate costumes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally the nectarine comes to rest ... downstage center! A second later Rover and Juliet catch up to it there. The the lights go down. A HUSH falls over the audience. The CONDUCTOR taps his baton and clears his throat. All e fall _on Rover and Juliet, who look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What are we supposed to do now?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Sing, I think.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Sing what?

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: (Whispering) Your first line is “Figaro.”

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Figaro? Suddenly the orchestra springs to life. Beautiful music fills the chamber. But Rover and Juliet struggle to sing operatically.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Figaro! Figaro!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Figaro! Suddenly, two underwear clad opera singers appear onstage begin chasing Rover and Juliet around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally making it back outside the opera house, Rover jum into a flowerbed and begins picking roses and daisies lef and right. Soon he has made a gigantic bouquet, which he presents proudly to Juliet. As Rover and Juliet come out the garden, a delightful smell wafts by and tempts their noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following the smell down the street, they come to “Domino Bakery.” Peering in the front window, they see a young APPRENTICE taking loaves of bread from the oven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unable to resist the smell of the fresh-baked bread, Rove and Juliet sneak into the bakery and creep nearer and nea the bread. But then Rover accidentally swats a pepper shaker with hi tail, making the Apprentice sneeze. The just risen loaves bread fall as flat as pancakes. The baker, SENOR DOMINO, becomes incensed and swats the Apprentice with his hat. A chase around the bakery begins, where the TOMATO and MOZZARELLA, which the baker was eating for supper, end up being spread on the FLATTENED LOAVES OF BREAD. Just as Senor Domino has the Apprentice cornered, he smel the PIE SHAPED CREATION on top of the stove. Suddenly he has an idea and cuts the pie into TRIANGULAR PIECES. After smelling one curiously, he plops it in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SENOR DOMINO
dialogues.text: Hey, that’s pretty good! As Senor Domino chomps down another bite, the Apprentice flattens out a bread box, making the first pizza box.

dialogues.speaker: APPRENTICE
dialogues.text: Wait a second, I got it! We’1ll deliver!

dialogues.speaker: SENOR DOMINO
dialogues.text: We'll call it Domino's! In their joy of their new discovery, they don’t notice ho Rover creeps up to the stove ... and swipes the first piz in the history of the world! On the way out the door, Juliet snatches the Apprentice’s bottle of milk, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet are riding in a gondola down the river, eating the pizza and drinking the milk and being serenade a quartet of string-playing crickets.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: It would go great with a little pepperoni, wouldn’t you say?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I think I'd prefer anchovies. When they come to an arched bridge, Rover takes Juliet’s and they're off again.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Come on!  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet continue their happy romp through town. Soon, they come to the Arena. Rover runs right through th front door.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: It’s the Arena!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet scamper up to the emperor’s box and look the Roman ruins around them.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Can you imagine what it was like back then? Suddenly, magically, the Arena is transformed into its classical glory! TOGA-CLAD SPECTATORS are doing “the wave”. GLADIATORS prepare to fight EXOTIC BEASTS. A wreathed sports announc looking an awful lot like Marv Albert does the play by pl In an instant, a WOOLY MAMMOTH charges at a gladiator in center of the ring. The gladiator is ROVER! Rover, however is too enamored of Juliet and doesn’t noti the tusked beast bearing down on him. Juliet meows ...! Just in time! Rover leaps to the side, using a toga as a Matador uses a cape. Within seconds, Rover has brought th beast to the ground, and has wrapped its trunk around its feet like a cowboy ropes a calf. Juliet tosses roses to Rover, who picks them up with his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An instant later, Rover and Juliet are dashing for the hi It’s all Flyer can do to keep up with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet sit side by side with all of Verona belo them. The sun is just coming up. They look deep into one another’s eyes ... Just as they begin to move closer to one another, Flyer c to the top of the hill and is hit by direct sunlight. Thi knocks his RADAR all out of whack and he promptly crashes into a CHICKEN COOP getting egg all over himself. Back on the top of the hill, meanwhile, all the other ani (except dogs and cats of course) have gathered around to Rover and Juliet move CLOSER and CLOSER.  46. When the young lovers kiss, it is like all of Italy sighs with them. Just seconds later, Flyer gets to the scene.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Darn, I missed the best part. Rover and Juliet look at him and then back at one another When they kiss again, Flyer literally shivers with happin Then they turn, paw in paw, and watch the sunlight contin to spread over Verona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verona still sleeps as Rover and Juliet return home from their adventure. When they reach The Cat-Pulets’ villa, t two young lovers stop at its gates and look at each other longingly.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Well ... Here we are.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (Sighing) Home.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Last night was amazing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I‘1l never forget it as long as I live.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I won’t either. Juliet starts under the gate.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I just wish ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I just wish we could do this every night.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: And every day, too.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But if our families ever found out ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: We'd never get to see each other again. The lovers tremble merely at the thought.  47.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: This feud is so dumb! I mean, cats and dogs aren't so different.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: We both walk on four legs ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: We both have tails ...

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: We both fall in love.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (Smiling) Yeah ... We both do, don’t we.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: You know, maybe there is a way we can be together and stop our two families from fighting.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But how?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Come with me. To the cathedral!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glorious renaissance church in the heart of Verona. THE CAMERA TRACKS UP the facade of the cathedral right into i bell tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flyer hangs upside down from the rafters, reading ‘How to Friends and Influence Animals.’ Rover and Juliet stand be

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: (Throwing down his book) You want me to WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I want you to marry us.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Don’t you think you’re moving just a little fast?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: It’s the only way, Flyer. Romeo told me that he and the girl Juliet were going to be married in the church ...

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: They were. The Friar performed the ceremony. It was a small but lovely affair.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Romeo also said that getting married would help end the feud between their two families.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: I gotta hand it to the boy, he’s sharp. Rover and Juliet look up at Flyer, knowingly. FLYER (cont'd) Oh ... I get it. You think you two could do the same for cats and dogs. The lovers smile and nod. FLYER (cont'd) Maybe, but I’m not a friar. I’m just a bat who lives in the belfry. That’s what bats do.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Please, Flyer. If it weren’t for you, Juliet and I wouldn’t even be together. All you have to do is say a few words. Nothing fancy.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: I don’t know ... Juliet notices the title of Flyer’s book and gets an idea

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Come on, Rover. Let’s go home. He’s just an old, scary-looking bat.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Now wait a second, young lady.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: It’s not like he wants to help end the feud between cats and dogs. I mean then everybody would like him. Nobody would be afraid of him anymore. Juliet’s reverse-psychology works. Flyer swoops down from the ceiling and stops them.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: I guess I could say a few words. I have watched enough weddings in my day. Rover and Juliet smile.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Come. Gather close. Flyer hovers in front of the couple.  49.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Do you, Rover, take Juliet to be your wife?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: You bet I do!

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: And do you, Juliet, take Rover to be your husband?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Yes. I do.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: Then by the power you have vested in me, I now pronounce you ... cat and dog. You may kiss the kitty. They kiss. As if on cue, the CHURCH BELLS begin to ring!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rover and Juliet climb out the window and onto the street Suddenly, RICE begins to fall on their heads. They both l up and find Flyer clutching a bag.

dialogues.speaker: FLYER
dialogues.text: What’s a wedding without rice? They smile and wave. Rover notices the people on the stre

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Wow, I better get you home.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: No, Rover. We better split up. At least until we tell our families the news.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Then we can be together whenever we want.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I can’t wait!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I’1l meet you back at your house with the rest of The Mongrels. I think we should tell everyone together.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I agree. Farewell, Rover. Parting is such sweet sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Hey, that’s kinda nice ... They sneak a final kiss and Juliet dashes off. Rover is l with a huge smile on his face.  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, the market place is bustling with people. INT. UNDER THE WATCHMAKER’S KIOSK Benny, Mercury and Big Daddy wait impatiently. Benny snatches one of the watchmaker’s watches and checks the t

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Where do you think Rover is?

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Don’t ask me. But he was acting pretty strange at the party last night.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: Speaking of The Cat-Pulet’s party, I heard what you boys did.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You should have seen it, Big Daddy. It was great!

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: No, Benny, it was stupid. Now all of the other animals probably hate us as much as the cats do. You pups need to pick your fights more carefully.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: But Big Daddy, those cats - Big Daddy rises over Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Big Daddy. We’1l be more careful. I promise. Rover finally arrives.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: And where have you been? You’re late.

dialogues.speaker: I... IT... I...
dialogues.text: Big Daddy waits for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Overslept?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (Whispering) Good answer.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: Because of your failure to pull off the butcher heist, Rover, The Mongrels went (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIG DADDY (cont'd) hungry. That’s not going to happen again ... (Looming over Rover) Is_it?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: No, Big Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BIG DADDY
dialogues.text: Today I’m sending you three on a mission even the dumbest dogs could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyger and his henchcats watch as The Mongrels sneak acros the marketplace. Tyger wears a gold WHISTLE around his ne

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Well if it isn’t our little friends the skunks ...

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Something is smelly in The State of Denmark.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: We’re in Verona, you idiot!

dialogues.speaker: SPEARE
dialogues.text: Et tu, Ty-gre? Tyger WHACKS them both across the head.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: SHUT UP! I have a plan to insure every mongrel in Verona thinks twice before messing with The Cat-Pulets again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs pick through the scraps. Mercury finds a T-Bone.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Look at this beauty!

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I better find one, too. I need to be on Big Daddy's good side today.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: What’s so special about today?

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: I have something important to tell the family.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? So tell us.  52.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Well ... Rover decides if he wants to spill the beans.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Tell us, Rover. The dogs look up and find the cats right behind them.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Tell us all what’s so important.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: So I see you brought your goons this time.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Goons?

dialogues.speaker: SPEARE
dialogues.text: He is a dog of most infinite jest. Tyger hisses at Shake and Speare. Then he approaches Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: I have some unfinished business with you Mongrels. A little payback for crashing our party. Rover gets between Tyger and Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Listen, we’re all very sorry about what we did, Tyger.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Rover? These fluffballs don’t deserve an apology. They deserve a nice bite on the behind.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: No, Mercury. Fighting isn’t the answer.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Then what is? Everyone looks at Rover.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Love. The cats and dogs break out in hysterics.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: This little doggie’s nuts! Benny steps forward and joins Rover.  53.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Maybe Rover's right.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Benny!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I don’t like fighting, Merc’. It’s really stupid. And for me, that’s saying a lot.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Looks like The Mongrels aren’t so tough after all. Mercury sticks his face up to Tyger’s.

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: Just try me, Pussy.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Remember what Big Daddy said, Merc’. We have to choose our fights more carefully.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: He's right, Merc’. Just take the bone and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: What’s it going to be? Are you a dog ... or a chicken? Mercury is ready to attack, but surprisingly, he steps ba

dialogues.speaker: MERCURY
dialogues.text: You ain’t worth it, Tyger. Mercury turns around and starts to walk away when suddenl TYGER POUNCES ON HIM, running his razor sharp claws down Mercury’s back. He draws blood.

dialogues.speaker: ROVER
dialogues.text: Why you ...! The henchcats grab Rover and Benny. Tyger has Mercury on back while he continues to claw him. Rover can’t stand to watch his friend being hurt. With al of his might, he shoves the henchcats to the ground and j on top of Tyger, pulling him off of Mercury. Rover gets Tyger pinned down. He opens his jaws, ready to bite the vicious cat. ROVER (cont'd) I don’t want to have to bite you, Tyger!

dialogues.speaker: TYGER
dialogues.text: Believe me, you’re not going to get the chance!  54. Tyger BLOWS on his gold whistle. At first, Rover doesn’t understand why. Then the sound of a horse approaching fas is heard.
